article_title: Things to do in and around Greenwich
article_text:
Things to do in and around Greenwich

Photo: Contributed / Contributed Photo Image 1 of / 1 Caption Close Image 1 of 1 The Greenwich Decorative Arts Society is holding its 30th annual luncheon and lecture at 10:30 a.m. Oct. 5 at The Greenwich Water Club, Cos Cob. Ulysses Grant Deitz, Chief Curator, Curator of Decorative Arts, Newark Museum, will discuss "Money, Beauty, Power: The Transformation of Taste in Americaís Gilded Age." Admission to the program is $60. Space is limited. Reservations required for members and guests by Sept. 25. For reservations and information, contact info@greenwichdecorativearts.org or call 203-322-2967. less The Greenwich Decorative Arts Society is holding its 30th annual luncheon and lecture at 10:30 a.m. Oct. 5 at The Greenwich Water Club, Cos Cob. Ulysses Grant Deitz, Chief Curator, Curator of Decorative Arts, ... more Photo: Contributed / Contributed Photo Things to do in and around Greenwich 1 / 1 Back to Gallery

For the latest events and activities happening in Greenwich, turn to For the Record. To have your event included, submit a description, date, time, price and contact information. Photos are welcome. Drop us an email about your latest goings-on at gtcitydesk@scni.com.

Obamacare focus of next RMA meeting

On Aug. 19 at 11 a.m. at First Presbyterian Church, Lafayette Place, Dr. John Hughes will discuss “Status and Future of the Affordable Care Act” at the next meeting of the Retired Men’s Association of Greenwich. Dr. Hughes, a renowned health policy expert, will give the Affordable Care Act a report card rating (A - F) on its various components, using objective criteria. He will also discuss its prospects for survival and for improvement. Dr. Hughes is a professor of medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine and has been a director of medical care at both the Yale-New Haven Hospital and the West Haven VA Medical Center in West Haven. Program is free and open to the public. Doors open at 10:40 a.m. For additional information, contact jim.fishbein1@verizon.net.

Cos Cob Old Timers picnic set

On Aug. 23 from 9:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. at Tod’s Point is the 31st annual Cos Cob Mianus Dugout old Timers picnic. Breakfast from 9:30 to 11 a.m., serving food and beverage until 6 p.m. Participants must be 21 or older and are allowed guests. Bring playing cards, horseshoes and bocce balls and other outdoor games. Tickets must be purchased in advance. Cost $50. Information and tickets at St. Lawrence Club, 203-618-9036 or Scarpelli’s, 203-869-2771.

At Home in Greenwich holds membership coffee

On Aug. 24 at 3 p.m. in Fletcher Hall at Second Congregational Church, 139 E. Putnam Ave., At Home in Greenwich Inc. is holding a coffee for seniors interested in membership and volunteering with the nonprofit, nonsectarian organization that enables Greenwich residents to remain in their homes as they age by providing them with vetted services, social activities and social work consultation. Meet with Executive Director Lise Jameson and current members. For information and reservations, call Lise at 203-422-2342.

Cos ‍Cob ‍Archers hold open shoot

On Aug. 30, the ‍Cos ‍Cob ‍Archers will hold an open-to-the-public field target/3D shoot at 205 Bible St. Registration takes place from 8 a.m. to 11 a.m. Cost: $5 for those younger than 16 accompanied by a paying adult, $20 for adults, $10 for non-shooting adults; $50 maximum per family, free for members, $10 for guests of members. Lunch is included. Guest bows/arrows for all ages are included in fee. To attend, email Bill Janhonen at wjanhonen@wsjenterprises.com. For further information, visit www.coscobarchers.com.

YWCA seeks volunteers to help serve domestic violence victims

On Aug. 31 at 9:30 a.m. at YWCA, 259 East Putnam Ave., is the beginning of the next training session for people interested in helping with the YW’s domestic violence services. YWCA Greenwich is looking for volunteers to work with domestic abuse services staff. The state-mandated training session runs through Sept. 3 from 9:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Attendance is mandatory. Application Forms can be downloaded by going to http://www.ywcagreenwich.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/DAS-15-Volunteer-Info.pdf or by contacting Meredith Gold at m.gold@ywcagreenwich.org or 203-302-3846.

Art classes, workshops offered

Dmitri Wright Fine Art Studio, 106 Hunting Ridge Road, has released the fall and winter catalog of classes and workshops. Available: Aug. 31 to Sept. 3, impressionist painting in Vermont’s Green Mountains. To register, contact 1-802-824-6673. Silvermine Art School, Fridays, 9 a.m. to noon or 1 to 4 p. m., Sept. 18 through Dec. 4, “Impressionism and Beyond.” Cost: $420 either session. Weir Farm Art Academy, four-day plein air workshop, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Oct. 19 through 22. Cost: $425. For more information, call 203-832-3325 or email DmitriWrightFineArt@gmail.com. For more classes, visit www.DmitriWright.com and www.WeirFarmArtAcademy.org.

Art exhibit slated

Through Aug. 31 at the Loft Artist’s Gallery, 575 Pacific St., Stamford, is the latest show of local artists, “Peak Season.” Work from at least 40 artists in painting, drawing, photography, sculpture, jewelry, collage, mixed media and print making. Gallery hours 1 to 4:30 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays. For information, call 202-247-2027 or visit loftartists.com.

Greenwich Choral Society to hold auditions

The Greenwich Choral Society, now in its 91st year, will be holding auditions for singers interested in becoming a member of the group. This year’s concerts will include masterworks by Bach, Vivaldi, Handel and Mendelssohn. Sopranos, altos, tenors and basses are invited to schedule an audition to be held at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich. Those interested may call Bill Fulton at 203-322-2990 or e-mail cbful@snet.net to schedule a time. For additional information, visit the Greenwich Choral Society’s website at www.GreenwichChoralSociety.org.

ESL, GED registration set

On Sept. 8 and 9 at 6 p.m. at Greenwich High School, Folsom House, 10 Hillside Road, is sign-up for the Greenwich Adult Learning Program’s English as a Second Language classes; and at 10 a.m. Sept. 8 and 10 at Havemeyer Building, 290 Greenwich Ave., and is signup for ESL and GED Preparation programs. For more information, call 203-625-7423.

Tween workshops slated

On Sept. 8, the Junior League of Greenwich will begin accepting reservations for “Positively More,” a program for girls ages 11 and 12 that aims to give girls the tools they need to avoid questionable situations, lessen the consequences of potential conflicts and identify the lessons learned by the challenges. Each session will consist of workshops moderated by professional in the fields of teen counseling, youth services and social media. Space is limited and will be filled on first come, first service basis. Register at jlgreenwich.org. For more information, email postivelymorejlg@gmail.com.

Registration open for memoir-writing course

On Sept. 9 at 9 a.m. at the Greenwich Library, 101 W. Putnam Ave., registration begins for a five-week course on memoir writing led by former New York Times editor Joan Motyka. The group will meet from 1 to 3 p.m. five Wednesdays beginning Sept. 30. Registration is required. Call Michele Martin at 203-625-6533 to register with your Greenwich or Perrot Library card number, or by using the Library’s online calendar/registration system at www.greenwichlibrary.org. Preference is given to Greenwich residents and first-time enrollees.

Historic Greenwich photos on display

Through Sept. 10 at Les Beaux Arts Gallery at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, an exhibit of old photos titled “Historic Greenwich” will be on display. Gallery hours are noon to 1 p.m. Sunday, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Monday through Thursday and 9 a.m. to noon Friday. The gallery is closed Saturdays and will be closed Sept. 7 in observance of Labor Day. The exhibit is free. For more information, call 203/869-1091 or visit roundhillcommunitychurch.org.

Reception, awards held for juried art show

On Sept. 10 from 5:30 to 8:30 p.m. at the Loft Artist’s Gallery, 575 Pacific St., Stamford, is the awards ceremony and opening reception for “Lineal Investigations,” a juried show running Sept. 10 through Oct. 11. Gallery hours: 1 to 4:30 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays. For information, call 203-247-2027.

Friends Friday Movie Series kicks off 68th season

On Sept. 11 at 8 p.m. at the Greenwich Library, 101 W. Putnam Ave., is the first offering of the 68th season of the Friends Friday Movie Series, “The One-Hundred Foot Journey.” Doors open at the library’s Cole Auditorium at 7:40 p.m. Free. Program made possible by funds from the Friends of the Greenwich Library. New this year: Flinn gallery will be open from 6 to 8 p.m. for exhibit viewing. Upcoming movies: Sept. 18, “Boyhood.” Sept. 25, “Far From the Madding Crowd” British, 1967. For complete list and more information, visit www.greenwichlibrary.org or call 203-622-7900.

Tag sale to benefit child seeks donations

On Sept. 12, friends of Bryce, a 3-year-old being treated for a brain tumor at Boston Children’s Hospital, will hold a tag sale to benefit the family. Donations are being accepted by Laura, 203-321-5352 or zarco444@gmail.com; Shanna, 203-912-4945 or espo0328@aol.com; or Mina, 203-536-7240 or tmjtb@optonline.net. For information on the child, visit www.gofundme/brycerocks. Rain date Sept. 13.

Rock concert to benefit Neighbor to Neighbor

On Sept. 12 from 4 to 6 p.m. in the parking lot at Diamond Hill United Methodist Church, 521 E. Putnam Ave., Cos Cob, will be a free rock concert to benefit Neighbor to Neighbor. Music by SoulShine of Mamaroneck, NY. Refreshments will be made available for purchase by Little Pub. In the event of rain, the concert will be held indoors. For more information, call 203-869-2395 or visit www.diamondhillumc.com.

Junior League holds new member open house

On Sept. 15 from 7 to 8:30 p.m. at 231 East Putnam Ave., the Junior League of Greenwich is holding and open house for new members. Cocktails and conversation about becoming a member of the Junior League of Greenwich. Meet current members and learn about the next new member class that begins Oct. 6. Free. For more information and to RSVP, call 203-869-1979 or email JLGNewMember@gmail.com.

Herb Fair slated

On Sept. 17 from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. at John Jay Homestead, 400 Route 22, Katonah, N.Y., the New York Unit of the Herb Society of America presents the 67th Annual Herb Fair. Admission is free; lunch is available. Specialties include gourmet foods and baked goods, herbs and other plants, books and gift items. A book signing by Carol Gracie, author of Spring Wildflowers of the Northeast, will take place at the Book Table. For more information, visit www.johnjayhomestead.org, or email herbsocietyny@gmail.com.

Friends hold children’s book sale

On Sept. 19 from 1 to 4 p.m. at the Cos Cob Library, 5 Sinawoy Road, is the Friends of the Library’s annual open house and children’s book sale. Entertainment by Airborne Jugglers, face painting, games, crafts and the prize drawings from the Summer Reading Club. Information, call 203-622-6883.

Pathways Volunteer Liz Menten to be honored at Benefit

On Sept. 19 at the Greenwich Country Club, 19 Doubling Road, is the annual Pathways gala to benefit housing and support services for the mentally ill. Pathways will honor volunteer Liz Menten. Entertainment to feature an encore performance of Broadway’s Nat Chandler and Sarah Pfisterer. For information about the Benefit, visit Pathway’s web site: www.pathways-Greenwich.org, or call 203-869-5656.

GHS Class of 1965 50th reunion

On Sept. 19 at the Sheraton Hotel, 700 E Main St, Stamford, the Greenwich High School Class of 1965 is having its 50th year reunion. Classmates who would like more information are asked to go to the website at ghs65reunion.com or call Gerry Petrizzi Pongonis at 203-846-9022 or Barbara Kolok Tiriolo at 203-445-8404. Weekend activities include golf, cocktail party, possible tour of town, football game and tailgating at the GHS football field, gala dinner/dance and picnic at Tod’s Point.

5K run/walk to benefit ONS Foundation

On Sept. 20 at 9 a.m. at Eastern Greenwich Civic Center, 90 Harding Road, Old Greenwich, is the third annual ONS Foundation 5K run/walk and health expo. On-site registration starts at 7 a.m. and group warm-up at 8:30 a.m. Post-race health and fitness expo. Proceeds from the 5K will benefit ONSF education and community outreach programs. Information, call 203-869-3131 or visit onsf.org.

Land Trust holds field day

On Sept. 20 from 3 to 6 p.m. at the Greenwich Polo Field is “Go Wild!” family fun day and hot air balloon launch to benefit The Greenwich Land Trust's conservation and ongoing land stewardship efforts. Events include bungee trampoline, rock wall, giant maze, surfing ride, food and drinks from local merchants and “Gunsmoke” will perform country and bluegrass music in the main tent. One ticket covers all activities and refreshments. Rain or shine. Tickets and information: http://bit.ly/1gPOnJa

Applications available for fall Citizen’s Police Academy

On Sept. 21 from 6:30 to 9 p.m. at the Greenwich Police Department, 11 Bruce Place, is the first meeting of the upcoming Fall Citizen’s Police Academy. Applications are now being accepted. Meets twice a week to learn how police and policing work. Course ends with Nov. 4 graduation. Seats limited. Submit application along with copy of drivers license to The Community Impact Section, Greenwich Police Dept., 11 Bruce Place, Greenwich, CT 06830 or email it to pstreet@greenwichct.org. More information on the Town of Greenwich website at greenwichct.org.

Abilis golf event set for 9/21

On Sept. 21 from 11:30 a.m. to 8 p.m. at Trump Links, Ferry Point, 500 Hutchinson River Parkway, the Bronx, is the Abilis golf event. Cost: $350 per golfer, $150 for dinner guests; sponsorship opportunities: $250 lunch, $500 dinner, $175 holes. Event includes brunch buffet, shotgun start, lunch and drinks on course and a pig roast. For information and registration, Keelin Daly at daly@abilis.us or 203-531-1880, Ext. 110.

Hamilton Avenue School alumni sought

On Sept. 26 will be a celebration of Hamilton Avenue School’s 100 years of Excellence in Education. Organizers of a reunion are seeking Hamilton Avenue alumni to attend. Reservations required. There will be no tickets sold at the door. People interested in an invitation are asked to e-mail Hamiltonavenue100@gmail.com or call 203-667-1682.

Lecture on Gilded Age slated

On Oct. 5 at 10:30 a.m. at the The Greenwich Water Club in Cos Cob, the Greenwich Decorative Arts Society will hold its 30th anniversary luncheon and lecture, “Money, Beauty, Power: The Transformation of Taste in America’s Gilded Age,” a lecture by Ulysses Grant Deitz, chief curator, Curator of Decorative Arts, Newark Museum. Cost: $60. Space is limited. Reservations required for members and guests by Sept. 25. For reservations and information, visit info@greenwichdecorativearts.org or call 203-322-2967.

Davidoff Cigar Golf Outing

On Oct. 5 at 10 a.m. at Fairview Country Club is the Davidoff Cigar Golf Outing. Limited to 72 golfers. Cost: $500 per golfer, $2,000 per foursome. Cost includes 18 holes, shotgun start, four Davidoff cigars, continental breakfast, caddy, cart, open bar the entire day and bar cart while playing, two longest drive and two closest to pin competitions with prizes; hole-in-one win a Maserati, steak and lobster dinner, full locker room access. for information, call 203-869-5401.

Chamber Players back in session in October

On Oct. 11 at 4 p.m. at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, and on Oct. 12 at 7:30 p.m. at the Bruce Museum, 1 Museum Drive, the Chamber Players of the Greenwich Symphony will kick off their 2015-16 season with “Vive la France” a musical salute to French composers. Classical harpist Victoria Drake will join the Chamber Players to perform works by Jongen, Saint-Saëns, Jolivet, Roussel, Devienne and Satie. Wine and cheese receptions are scheduled for each concert. Cost: adults $30, students $5. For more information, call 203-637-4725 or visit online at http://www.greenwichsymphony.org/chamber-players-greenwich-symphony.

Central Catholic HS plans 50th reunion

On Oct. 17 from 6 to 11 p.m. at The Shore and Country Club, 220 Gregory Blvd., East Norwalk, is the Central Catholic High School Class of 1965’s 50th Reunion. The Reunion Committee is still looking for many classmates. Graduates of the Class of 1965 interested in attending should contact the Committee at CCHS65Norwalk@hotmail.com or visit the website at CCHS65Norwalk.com. The CCHS Classes of '63, '64, '66 and '67 are also invited to attend. For further information, contact Tina Gardner at 203-858-1843 or Brian Power at 401-391-9430.
